File JEEA MS5073-1 R1's report.txt

  • → Referee Rep..5073-1 R1's report.txt ↘ 

  • Referee Reports/JEEA MS5073-1 R1's report.txt open
file:doc:txt
  • All properties 
    key content
    date Sat Jan 11 13:28:50 CET 2014

    • Content

      Content: this paper presents the results of an experiment to elicit individual subjective probabilities in condition of uncertainty. The uncertainty is operationalized by (real incentivized) bets on the winner of a car race. The probability of winning of each car is unknown to the subject (but it is known to the researcher).  Main finding: the subjective probabilities elicited follow the typical inverse-S shape that has been repeatedly found in empirical elicitations in decision under risk. The best fit of this inverse-S shape probability weighting function is provided by the Prelec two-parameter family.





A.	The paper is well written, well presented, the topic is of interest to a top journal such as JEEA. Experimental design is sound. Data analysis is sound. A central contribution of this paper, according to the authors, is the estimation of probability weighting functions under uncertainty (ie unknown probabilities). On top of page 4 the authors claim that every study to estimate a probability weighting function does so under risk (ie, probabilities known). As a matter of fact the paper misses the KEY point that in the decision theory literature the probability weighting function in the case of unknown probabilities (ie, uncertainty) has been already measured. I suggest the authors to look at Abdellaoui et al 2011, AER and its references, for example Kilka and Weber (2001) one of the first attempts to do the measurement in a formal and efficient manner. In addition, these papers were also able to elicit the utility functions. So the main novelty of the current paper is undermined. Bottom line: there exist already well-established studies of probability weighting function in the domain of uncertainty (ie, with probabilities not known to the decision maker)  

B.	The main difference of the current paper (wrt to previous literature) is to present the elicitation in a dynamic and real setting where probabilities are unknown to subject but known to researcher. The setting is the domain of bets on a winner in a simulated car race. This is a very nice domain and it mimics the original de Finettiâ€™s horse race (1931, 1937) that he used to introduce the idea of subjective probabilities. This setting is pretty exciting and the design is such that the authors can observe the update of uncertain probabilities. This is interesting and rather innovative. However, also in this case there is no connection with the vast (theoretical) literature on the update of subjective probabilities under expected utility and under nonexpected utility. I strongly suggest the authors to connect to this literature. 

C.	What is the advantage to have an experimental design that allows allocating part of the money into a bet and part into an investment (to decrease the incidence of the downward shock)? In terms of probability elicitation, what is the advantage of having this choice? I suspect it may actually be an unwanted obstacle to the task to elicit subjective probabilities in an efficient and neat manner. I suggest the authors to clarify this aspect. 

D.	I would prefer to receive more precise details on the measurement of the subjective probabilities. In fact on one hand I understand that there is a betting task, ie, a choice on how to allocate money into cars, but on the other hand there is also a direct question on the likelihood of their car winning at the beginning of the race and after each pit stop. What is the relation between the two measurements? I can see some thoughtful considerations in section 4.1 but I am still missing this clear link. This is not clarified by reading the appendix with the instructions of the game. 

E.	Page 12, before figure 1: does it mean that there is a sort of discontinuity in the probability weighting function close to 1? This is pretty interesting and it was originally postulated in Kahneman and Tversky 1979.

F.	Can the authors improve the quality of figure 1?

G.	I suggest getting deeper into the analysis of learning which is only alluded at on page 16.

H.	A discussion of the results is required. Section 6 is merely a summary of results.
